transcript.content: Well, episode two of season three of the Ricky Gervais show with me. Ricky Gervais, Stephen Merchant. Hello there. And Carl Pilkington. All right, what's been going on? What's been going on?
I've been to hospital. I was rushed to hospital. Emergency in that. Had a tube put on my knob.
You had a tube put up your knob?
Yeah.
What's the story?
Kidney stones. So shouldn't really be here, to be honest, doing this. He said rest. Climbing them stairs on the way in.
To be quite honest, it doesn't look like you're expending a lot of energy at the moment. It's like at zookeeper going, all that sloth move today. Calm down.
Yeah, but I had to get here. It's been raining.
Yeah.
Come up the stairs. I had to carry the computer.
Yeah, well, that's not entirely true because your girlfriend was carrying it. I saw her outside.
Yeah, but I'm just saying.
And then you handed it to me and said, steve, carry this.
Yeah, I know.
That's already a lie.

Christ almighty whinging, not whinging. I'm in show business. I know loads of people that wake up every day with a sore knob feeling like they've had their kidneys probed and they. They, you know, they would say they're unconscious, so they don't whinge about it. They get straight back onto it. A lot of them on TV now.
Yeah.
Straight back to hosting game shows.
So you're us to hospital.
So take us through the. Take us through the events. Because it does sound quite dramatic. You started feeling a bit of pain, did you?

Initially, I felt a bit of pain and I thought, you know, maybe I've just pulled a muscle or something when I've been wrestling with Ricky and that, because you don't know what damage is being done. So I just think, oh, it'll go in a minute. And then it didn't. It got a bit badder.
It got bader, did it?
So then I thought I was crippled. I was lying on the floor in agony, looking on the Internet, looking for.
Still looking at monkey news.

I was just. I just put in like bellyache and stuff. And they were saying it can be loads of different things. And I. What I used to do when I was a kid, I used to always just get a cold ashtray and put that on my belly. And the coldness used to get rid of the badness.
Amazing. The coldness got me like a witch doctor.
This is like a witch doctor happens to work in a pub.
It's like some sort of 5th century remedy written in mud. Coldness doth get away with the badness.
Why specifically an ashtray?
Just because they were the sort of old cold.
They're old cold.
I don't know what this is.

I love this idea that he had the operation and he comes around and they're talking to him and his girlfriend gets a phone call and go. And they say, Mr. Pilkerton's maybe complications. He's just talking rubbish. She goes, oh, good.
Yeah, he's back to his old self. Why specifically an asterisk? Sorry, it's old cold. I understand it's old cold.
Oh, yeah, we understand. Everyone who's done a medical degree understands old cold.
But.
Old cold Belly Madness, if you want to buy that book, Old Cold Belly Madness, it's the History of Abdominal Surgery by Carl Pilkington.
No, it just, you know.
But can you put it in the freezer or something?
You can do if you want, but they're normally cold anyway. Sort of thick glass. And I holds the cold. But we don't smoke in our house, so I had to use a plate.
Oh, well, that's madness. A plate's not gonna work. Famously, a plate doesn't work.
God, no.
So you put a plate on your belly, but that didn't do anything.
That didn't work. So called Suzanne and said, oh, I'm in agony here. She said, go to the doctors then.
Good advice. A lot of people have done that straight away, as opposed to go through the plate.
Ashtray, Ashtray.
So we got into hospital one night, he went to hospital and he said, you got an ashtray?
This is no smoking.
So anyway, so then we get in a cab and whatever. You go there, I have an X ray.
His voice is even more boring than usual, isn't it? Me.

And they put me on a drip and everything, give me some morphine stuff and found out that I had kidney stones. So that's why I was in hospital. And they get them out by. I can't even. And so there's a little tube up the end of your knob into you.

But why do you have the thing where they go in the side? You had the choice to.
Because I said to the doctor, I said, I'm Not a doctor. I said, what do you think?

Sorry. The choice was have it done properly or go home.

And I said, oh, flesh it out.
No, because it's too big. It's something like 7 millimeters.

Yeah. Certain now.

Yeah.

Stop measuring it.

Do you mean, what is the first and lowest and most primitive and most simple form of life?
He's right here in this room.
Say like when you look at a stick insect, right, you go, right, there's a slight cross over there from a stick to a living thing.
No, it's not.
It didn't used to be a stick.

Of course there is. There isn't.

You can't see him. That's the same as the sticking stick.

Doesn't use them. It goes around floating in the air on a bit of webbage.

Her birthday and flashbacks from an incident. Yeah, like he's some sort of, like, war veteran. What is it?
It's the wasp.
It could have killed a kitten.

Bought some wallpaper. We got back and got on with it. The wall that we've papered before has got a big mirror under it. We papered on top of it again. I ended up reading my phrase book whilst Suzanne did the rest of the tidying up. Now, what's your phrase book? This is just you trying to master English, is it?
It's just a book that tells you little sayings and how they came about.

An interesting phrase is pot luck. It came about when all people ate is stews. They used to chuck all sorts of stuff into the stew you stuck your spoon in and sometimes you got something nice, like beef. Or you could end up with a bit of frog.
It's potluck. Good night, isn't it?
That's what it said in the book, didn't it?
A bit of frog.

Got up and checked the wallpaper out. There are loads of air bumps and it's buckled on the joins. I wish we'd never done it. Suzanne said the washer was broke and it's out of its warranty. She called up the people who made it and they said it will cost 150 to fix. I don't know how they know that when they haven't even seen it. I want to smash it to bits and see what they can do for us as she could. So much anger.
I want to smash it to bits. That'd be great, wouldn't it?
150. You sure come round and it's just like a cube that's been through one.
Of those car crashers.
150 quid. There's 150 quid. Fix it.

I watched the news and calmed down a bit because there was a story about some Siamese twins who are having an operation. They've got two heads, four arms, two legs, one liver. The doctor said they will have one leg each. I felt bad worrying about the washer when people have bigger problems like the Siamese twins. Ricky and Steve asked me to do a poem about one day a week, so I thought I'd do one today. I can't obviously do it justice. I should let the master read it.
You've done another poem?
Yeah. You said, you know, just do one. If you have a day where you've had a lot of emotions.
Well, I loved the poem and so did the listeners, and I knew they would. So if you can do that every week, that would be a joy to me.
You can't force a poem, though.
No, I know diary is easy to.
Do because you just write down what you doing.
But you've got some really meaty subject matter to be able to write a poem, Rick, as you're discovering.
I know, right.
So you know, you've heard what problems I had that day.
Go on.
In bubbled wallpaper. What a mess. Washer dry and knackered. What a mess. Siamese twins separated one leg.
I don't know what rhyming scheme that is again. Oh, God. Oh, God.
Oh.
Fuck me.
Well, there you go. That's the end of episode two of series three of the Ricky Gervais Show. More next week. More drivel. More diary. Another poem, I hope.
Maybe.
Just more news and stuff from me. Ricky Gervais, Steve Merchant.
Goodbye.
And Carl Pilkington.
Right.
